Dr. Brick Cements Hop Fraternities Migrate North;
Intellectuals' Stand 'Canterbury Tale' Ends Well
Against Draft Call
By JIM DAVIS
Dr. Allan Brick, a former professor of English at Goucher College, and presently Director of
Peace Education for the Society
of Friends in the Middle Atlantic
States, addressed a meeting of
eDS last Tuesday evening at Lev
bring Hall.
In his address, Dr. Brick stated
that SDS had in recent months
been among the foremost agitators against the draft, and that
the October protests had been inS,trumental.in bringing the attention of the government to the
fact that there does exist serious
Oitellectual opposition to the
Vietnam conflict in American
Society.
"Depraved War"
He also commented on the case
With which the liberal view in
American politics finds expression in the press. Any anti-war
demonstration is given good publicity. He expressed fear, however, that such publicity might
serve only to cement opinion
against the aims of the demonstrators.
Dr. Brick further said that he
does not believe 'that America
has ever engaged in war-making
in so depraved a manner as it is
presently engaged in Vietnam. He
said that there might be a tendency on the part of the governmental bureaucracy to try to
justify itself by conducting such
a war.
Objection of Youth
Broaching the main topic of

ALAN BRICK
his address, the draft and conscientious objection, he said that
conscientious objectors were becoming more numerous, with one
CO for every 400 men ordered to
report for induction. He attributed this at least in part to the
growing objection of middle class
youth to service in Vietnam.
He further stated that the government was seeking to counter
this growing opposition by hints
of alternative service in the Peace
Corps or VISTA.
He believed, however, that the
vast majority of middle class
America was not willing to stand
up for its principles to the extent
of going to jail. He also pointed
to a lack of knowledge, especially
on the part of lower class persons eligible for the draft, of the
details or even the existence of
conscientious objection.
As an instance, he mentioned

By GARTH MACKENZIE
If one were to conduct a short
investigation of the situation of
American fraternities, he would
probably find that nearly every
major university in the country
has its so-called fraternity row.
At the University of Maryland,
as is the wide-spread case, the
fraternities are clustered together on university owned land;
they are, correspondingly, considered campus organizations
and are therefore subject to all
campus restrictions on the use
of alcohol, social functions, and
gaiety in general.
To maintain efficient control over the sororities and fraternities, the university provides
each one with a house mother,
whose duty it is to keep the
members in line.
At Hopkins, however, the situation is distinctively different.
In accordance with the University's policy of non-interference,
the 14 social fraternities are
scattered more or less randomly
in the area immediately surrounding the campus. Their
houses stand on privately-owned
land and are owned or rented by
the national chapters.
Canterbury Road is the closest
thing Hopkins presently has in
the way of a fraternity row. Five
houses, including TEP, Beta, Phi
Gam, Phi Sig, and DU, are now
located either on Canterbury Rd.
or in the near vicinity.
The other houses stand along
Charles, St. Paul, and Calvert
Streets in the old area to the
south of the campus. The neighborhood condition in this section
is worsening—in the past few
weeks there has been an increasing number of incidents involv-

ing vandalism against both
houses and brothers.
If this decay continues, inevitably many of these fraternities will attempt to relocate
themselves north of Homewood
—most probably in Canterbury.
Move To Canterbury
When Phi Sigma Delta became the first Hopkins fraternity
to move onto Canterbury Rd.
several years ago, there 'was a
great amount of resistance from

the inhabitants of this exclusive neighborhood. The problem
culminated in the appearance
before the Maryland Supreme
Court of a law suit designed to
oust the fraternity from Canterbury. It was defeated.
Since then, as the other fraternities moved into the section,
the neighbors have constantly
complained about noisy parties,
parking problems, and general

Editor's Note: This is a dispatch wired to the News-Letter
early this week describing recent
ROTC training exercises at Fort
Meade.
Special to the News-Letter
By PETER BROWNBACK,
war correspondent

Rotten, lousy, miserable weather prevailed as it usually does
when the Army is getting ready
to send its men into combat. At

night it was cold enough to make
a man wish for his gloves, but
the orders to wear them has not
yet been given.
There had been none of the
usual joking in the barracks tonight. Instead, the time had been
spent polishing the boots and
cleaning the rifles.
Everyone wanted to be sure
that his rifle would not misfire
the next day, and they all tried

desperately to remember what
Sergeant Funk had told them
about the best way to insure
safe firing. ,
Not many of the men felt
like talking anyway. They were
thinking their own thoughts and
reconciling themselves with what
was to be. A lot of their thoughts
went back to the training which
was to be so important the next
day. Three courses were most
clearly remembered.
Major Stultzenmueller's course
in fire and maneuver was one of
these. Fire and maneuver, the
basic means of advancing on an
enemy who has a better tactical
position, would enable them to
be effective in case they encountered a larger force of the
aggressor.
Sergeant-Major Ray's course
in combat formations would enable their squad leader to control them without having to explain step by step what he wanted them to do.

Their mission was to provide
confirmation of intelligence given
by the POW's to the S-3, the intelligence officer. This was to be

The dispute over the refusal
of the Marylander barber shop
to give haircuts to Negroes, including those who are students
at Hopkins, continues with the
prospect of Student Council action a possibility.
The Student Council discussed
the matter at their weekly meeting and voted to allot two dollars to Alan Beal, a Hopkins
student and a Negro in order to
get a haircut at the Marylander.
Beal was refused service by the
manager on the grounds that he
(the manager) was not trained
to cut a Negro's hair. He subsequently stated that none of the
other barbers working in his
shop have the necessary training.
Sam Barranco, manager of the
Hopkins Barber Shop in Levering Hall concurred. He said that
"cutting a colored man's hair
does require extra training" and
that "most barbers in Baltimore
don't have the training." He
added, however, that "Here at
Hopkins we do the best for anyone regardless of color, race or
creed."
As an additional tactic, the
student delegation which confronted Mr. De Ruggiero, also

discussed the matter with the
manager of the Marylander
Apartments, the building in
which the barber shop is located.
When the students presented the
possibility of a picket outside
the apartments, he said that he
did not care.
The conflict was precipitated
a few weeks ago when Victor Da
Ruggiero, the manager of the
barber shop refused to cut the
hair of a Negro who was also a
Hopkins student. Last week, a
group of students decided to
take action and called a meeting
of Hopkins students to discuss
the situation. It was decided at
the meeting that a delegation of
students should speak to Mr. De
Ruggiero and try to obtain concessions from him. If that failed,
a picket and boycott were
planned.
The delegation met with the
barber who allegedly said that
he would give haircuts to Negroes one day each week. Not
satisfied, Stephen Shriver, who
chaired the student meeting on
the controversy, pressed for wider
concessions. According to Shrivel-, Mr. De Ruggiero finally
agreed to cut the hair of any
Hopkins student..

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOVEMBER 18, 1 966

White Launches Italian Art
'Roses' Star Has
`Agammemnon' Lead Rescue Fund Drive in Area
Irene Dailey, star of the offBroadway hit "Subject was
Roses", has been signed to play
the lead in the Theatre Hopkins
production of "Agammemnon".
The Greek tragedy by Aeschlus
will be performed under the auspices of the Amos E. Taylor Jr.
Memorial Drama Evening on
Sunday evening, January 15.
Miss Dailey, winner of the Vernon Rice Award for best performance given by an actress offBroadway and director of. the
well known acting school, The
Company of ,The Actors in New
York City, will play the role of
Clytemnestra, while being supported by several guest characters.
The drama series sponsored by
the parents of a Hopkins student
who died in World War II, is
usually a reading, but this year's
will be a performance of the
play. The play will be a contemporary interpretation in verse
by William Alfred, who is well

known for the writing of "Hogan's Goat". This was his first
play.
Student Roles Open
Hopkins students who possess
both the talent and the interest
in performing alongside actors
and actresses of Miss Dailey's
caliber should take a special note
of the fact that approximately
three roles will be open for students. Interested
individuals
should contact Theatre Hopkins
director Edward Golden.
Mr. Golden will be directing
the January 15th production;
sets will be by Tony Mazzaro;
and lighting will be by Robert
Hassinger. Tickets are on sale in
the Special Events Ticket office
in Shriver Hall.
Over two thirds of the seats
have already been sold. It is possible, if the need arises, that another performance will be held.
Tickets are two dollars for general admission and one dollar
and fifty cents for students. Special group rates are available.

By M. PAUL
Dr. John White, Chairman of
the History of Art Department
here, was named this week to
head regional operations of Jacqueline Kennedy's Committee to
Rescue Italian Art.
The aim of the committee will
be to contribute financial support to the salvage and restoration of works of art damaged
when floods ravaged northeastern Italy last week.
Worst Disaster
The disaster has been called
Italy's worst in recent history.
Estimates of damage range into
the billions of dollars for works
of art alone.
Hard hit by the high rising
flood waters were the Uffizi Galleries, the National Library,
Giotto's Campanile, the Pazzi
Chapel, San Lorenzo and the
Medici Chapels.
In Venice, waters reached their
highest flood level in two centuries, and experts fear that the
city, its foundations weakened,

JOHN WHITE
is in danger of collapsing.
Completely Destroyed
Works by Bottieelli, Filipo
Lippi, Maasaccio, and Simone
Martini were completely destroyed.
Informed sources estimate that
20 years will be needed to restore what remains.

organizational
meeting
first,

Peabody Conservatory, and the
Hopkins public relations department.
Officials Sent
Both the Walters and Haitimore Museum have already sent
officials to Florence to help with
restoration.
No financial goal has been set
by the group yet, but a fund
raising program is in the planning.
The committee expects to work
principally through direct solicitations, museum activities, activities among art dealers, and
musical events.
The University itself, lending
the use of its public relations
department and forming several
student committees, will also be
a focal point.
Contacted Leaders
White estimated that his entire committee will consist of
30 to 40 members. He has already
contacted several Maryland politicos, civic, and religious leaders.
"We need a lot of people to
take a little interest," he said.
"School children, Lions Clubs,
and Rotary Clubs—it will aZ
add up."
The committee's first planned activity will be a concert
co-sponsored by the Peabody
Conservatory and Walters Art
Gallery December 1.
White himself will appear on
WBAL TV's "One Man's Opinion" tonight in an effort to
stimulate local interest.
Going Well
"At the moment things are
going well," he said. "Both of
the museums have sent circulars
to their memberships to let them
know what kind of activities
will be going on.
—The Italians could spend their
entire budget on art restoration
alone," White added, "but this
Is a major economic disaster foi
them, too.
"Even before the floods, Italy
was spending millions for restoration and was worrying about
the foundations of Venice."

One of the season's most important art events will take
place at The Baltimore Museum
of Art beginning December 13
when the museum presents "Andrew Wyeth: A Comprehensive
Exhibition."
The Baltimore Museum of Art
is one of the three museums in
the country to hold the exhibition following its opening presentation at The Pennsylvania
Academy of Fine Arts which organized this ambitious assemblage of works. Wyatt is considered America's pre-eminent realist painter, and perhaps the
most popular of America's living artists.
Wyeth is almost always classified as a realist, though he may
not describe himself as such. His
paintings are representational,
that is, the objects are recognizable and familiar—people, boats
animals, windows, landscape—
but what he does with color,
composition and his own creative
expression may not go down in
art history as pure realism.
Agnes Mongan of the Fogg
Art Museum, an authoritative
critic of Wyeth, wrote in a recent
publication about him: "As is
true of every real artist, his preference and use saf color is deeply
personal, again often with symbolic overtones. He loves the
colors of dry grass and of fresh
grass, and the russet of autumn
leaves, 'the dusty beauty' of a
winter beehive, olive-greens and
mustardy yellows, the contrast
of silvery and golden tones, and
over and over, or more than a
note, of blue: the faded, worn
blue of an old denim coat, a
blue measure, a blue scale, a
blue mussel shell, a patch of blue
water, a bit of blue sky, or a box

or two of blueberries.
"In the best sense of the
word, Andrew Wyeth is a regional artist, for the scenes he
draws and paints are chosen
from two regions he knows and
loves so well. But in the last
analysis the drawings and paintings are no more regional than
the seasons themselves and the
effects these seasons have on the
lives of those who live in and
through them."
Many of the best paintings by
Wyeth will be shown in the
forthcoming exhibition, including "Maga's Daughter", 1966,
lent by the artist; "The Mill",
1958, lent by Mrs. Andrew Wyeth; "Four Poster", 1946, lent by
Mr. and Mrs. Roger Milliken of
South Carolina; "Young America", 1950, lent by the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts;
"Grape Wine", 1966, lent by M.
Knoedler and Company, New
York; and "The Slip", 1958, lent
by Mrs. Andrew Wyeth.
Altogether, some 200 paintings
and drawings will be shown,
drawn from museums and private collections around America.
An admission charge of $1.00
to the Wyeth exhibition areas
will be made; general admission
to the rest of the museum will be
free as always.
An informative and handsomely illustrated catalogue on the
exhibition is available for purchase at the museum. In the introduction to the catalogue, the
Director of the Pennsylvania
Academy of Fine Arts, Joseph T.
Fraser, Jr., states: "After more
than half a century of art built
on a rejection of nature, our age
is not well equipped to underStand the painter's use of imaginative observation.

tire week and not just weekends.
Goucher President Kraushaar
sent the approved curfew to the
Student Organization Monday.
Previously, the program had
been unanimously approved by
the Student Activities Committee
and overwhelmingly approved in
a school referendum.
The curlew is similar to the
one which was proposed for the
entire school last year. That one
was defeated by the SAC. The
matter was reopened this Year
by changing the resolution so
that it applied only to the senior
and junior classes.
Kraushaar, in approving the
curfew, stated, "To reduce the
risks of trying out the curfew
proposal, I'm approving the selfdetermined curfew for a one
year period for the senior class
only."
Reliable Goucher sources said
that there was a possibility of
the curfew being extended to
juniors later in the year.

breakfast.

The current graduating class not only remembers
President Truman and President Eisenhower, it came
of age with the election of President Kennedy. The class
of 1967 missed Class Day because the President was shot.

Ellison has written, "Harlem is
the scene and symbol of the
Negro's perpetual alienation in
the land of his birth." Harlem as
Norman Mailer has reflected is
a kind of hell within a hell.

Students, Faculty To Mix
Faculty members and students will have the opportunity
to mingle informally every week
at Levering. Starting December
I, an informal coffee hour will
be held in the Sherwood Room
every Thursday.

will be able to mingle and chat.
There will be no structured
format. People will be free to
come and go as they please.
Refreshments will be provided
during the hour. The coffee and
donuts will be free.

The program is being coordinated by Bill Benzon, SA cabinet member, and Dr. Neville
Oyson-Hudson, anthropologist.
the two have sent letters to all
taculty members and have obtained commitments from many
faculty members to drop in during the hour.
The professors and students

In citing the need for this
program, Benzon quoted from
the Undergraduate catalogue,
"But above all, a university is a
community of people bound together in a magnificent enterprise, the enterprise of learning."
According to Benzon, most of
the interaction between professors and students comes on a

"functionary" level, as students
and teachers. "There is not
enough contact as people," he
stated.
Benzon added that if the response to the coffee hours was
favorable, the program could be
expanded.

OF THE EVER POPULAR ADLER HOSIERY

By M. PAUL
The Campus Parking and Traffic Committee will act this month
on proposals to erect a five-story
parking garage west of the Aeronautics Building.
If an informal campus poll
shows favorable interest in the
structure, the Committee will ask
for University approval early in
1967.
No plans have been drawn yet
for the garage, but the area has
been surveyed by a consulting
firm hired by the Parking Committee.
Park It Yourself
The firm recommends a multilevel, self-park, pay garage, containing space for 927 cars. Estimated cost is $2,500,000.
Construction would be financed
by government loans, to be paid
off through parking fees. Garage
privileges would cost approximately $23.00 per space annually.
The University currently has
parking space for 962 cars. Its
largest lot, number four, contains
240 spaces.
Permits Issued
At the same time a total 9,500
parking permits have been issued

for the 1966-67 school year.
"There is a need for more space
for both the day and evening
school," said William Campbell,
Assistant Plant Manager.
"The problem is worse at night
school, but it's also severe between ten in the morning and
three in the afternoon."
No short term solutions have
been proposed, but Campbell
noted that the employment of
additional parking guards this
year has helped control the situation to a certain degree.
Park on Streets
He also remarked, however,
that problems have been compounded ever since the city
tightened parking regulations on
streets surrounding the campus.
"The city put in two-hour
meters on the south side of Art
Museum Drive and a two-hour
parking limit on the north side,"
he pointed out."Formerly, streets
like this would handle our overflow."
A garage is favored over the
surfacing of more lots since a
building would take up less
space, according to the Parking
Committee.

By HENRY M. HOCHERMAN
Upon entering the Eisenhower
Library these days, one can not
help but have his eyesight assailed by a collection of cardboard
and paint purported to be an
architect's rendering of the New
South Quad. Sick and tired —Of
being behind in the University
Space Race, the stately old Hop
Will add 700,000 square feet
(enough room to put down 4,345,786 No Doz tablets end to
end) of office and classroom
sPace in the next 25 years. Wonderful.
The new buildings, designed by
Horatio W. Shubocks, president
Of the famous architectural firm
Ott Shubocks, Redbrick, Trimsworth and Gauche, will abandon
the old Georgian style for which
the Hopkins has long been noted,
and will adopt a new, modern
look, a cross, it would appear,
between Long Island High School
Provincial and International
House of Pancakes contemporary, an architectural form very
Popular among the more forward looking state schools. Architect Shubocks, who made his
name in the packaging industry
designing the now famous Cap'n
Crunch and Nabisco Shredded
Wheat boxes, has applied his
Packaging talents to architecture. "We get more space," he
has been quoted as saying, "by
sticking to tried and true principles. None of this old time
Georgian stuff for me." In keeping with Mr. Shubocks' architectural ideals, the New South
Quad will appear, from the air,
much like a collection of Kleenex
boxes worshipping a central milk
container. Purists need not fear
however, for Plant Manager
Wesley Taylor, who is working
hand in glove with Shubocks, has
assured the Hopkins community
that the new buildings will be of
red brick construction and will
be crowned with white trim. An
audible sigh of relief was heard
at this declaration.
Problems of Georgian fenestration have been eliminated by
eliminating windows, in keeping
With the great aesthetic precedent set by the New Classroom
Building, and the buildings will
of course be fully air conditioned
for those who enjoy artificial air

The Bell System has many small, automatic
telephone offices around the
country.The equipment in them
could operate unattended for
ten years or so, but for a problem.
The many electric motors in those offices
needed lubrication at least once a year. Heat
from the motors dried up the bearing oils,
thus entailing costly annual maintenance:
To stamp out this problem, many tests
were conducted at Bell Telephone
Laboratories. Lubricant engineer George H. Kitchen decided
to do a basic experiment that
would provide a motor with the
worst possible conditions. He deliberately set

out to ruin some ball bearings
by smearing them with an
icky guck called molybdenum
disulfide (MoS2).

STUDY IN
SOUTHERN FRANCE

Swock! This solid lubricant, used a certain
way, actually increased the life expectancy
of the ball bearings by a factor
often! Now the motors can run
for at least a decade without
lubrication.
We've learned from our
!`failures." Our aim: investigate
everything.
The only experiment that can
really be said to "fail" is the
one that is never tried,

I'm a big football star, and I've found a girl who suits me to a T. But

from A Mr Pi R2 to E Ma Now she says he's found the formula
for success with her. All he has to do is mutter "Coronet R/T," and
I get thrown for a loss. Believe me, this is no equilateral triangle
that I'm in. Qutside of telling me to bench myself, have you any
advice?

DEAR FALLEN STARi
Now's the time to plunge. Coronet R/T isn't his exclusive formula. Your nearby Dodge Dealer has it,
too. And it comes almost as easily as the cube root of
27. Then how can the girl of your dreams resist two
superstars . . you and your Coronet R/T? From
there on out, your math major will be the victim of
diminishing returns. Huddle with your Dodge Dealer
now,and get your signals straight.

By JEFF LAUREN
After splitting its last two
games, the varsity soccer team
will try to end the season on a
winning note tomorrow at Dickinson.
Saturday the Bluejays were
trying for their third straight
win but were stopped cold by
Drexel, 2-0. Hopkins was hampered by the absence of Pablo
Drobny, the team's high scorer,
and defensive starters Roger
Purdom and Stu Hogdson. Hodgson suffered a torn thigh muscle
and is out for the season.
Coach Gary Barrette shuffled his players in an attempt
to make up for the losses as
he shifted Dave Rockwell to
halfback and put Ken Torrington
in Rockwell's fullback spot. But
he could not help the Bluejays
score. They all played well, but
missed their chances to score
when they took eight shots in
the first period without any hitting.
Then with only a minute and
a half left, in the first period,
Drexel scored two goals and the
game was over. Hopkins was outshot 17-15, but hustled most of
the game until they tired in the
last period.
The Drexel goalie made some
spectacular saves to keep the
Bluejays from scoring. Soph Carl
Ahrendt started in place of
Drobny, and showed poise and
good play.
Tuesday the Jays traveled to

Western Maryland looking for a
victory. This time co-captain
Drobny was able to play and he
sparked Hopkins to a 5-2 win,
bringing their season record to
three victories and six losses. The
defense was tight and played another fine game as they have
shown continual improvement
from mid-season on.
On offense, Drobny kicked two
goaLs, making that thirteen for
the season. Wes Bachur had his
best day of the year, also scoring two goals. Scoring number
five, sophomore Art Guerin got
his first goal of the season.
Guerin, the high sewer on last
year's freshmen team, has been
a starter all season, and has
played well throughout. He
scored Tuesday on a header from
a corner kick.
A Better Half
Barrette has high hopes for
tomorrow's game against Dickinson. He feels that if the Bluejays can win tomorrow, then
their season would be more successful than their record shows.
They would have won four out
of their last five games after
their 0-5 start.
Dickinson is 2-7 on the year,
but is much better than its record. They lost several close
games to good teams. For comparison, Dickinson beat Washington College 5-1, while Hopkins won by a score of 4-1. Both
teams should be evenly matched.
with a good battle in the making.,

Dr. Allan Brick, a former professor of English at Goucher College, and presently Director of

fact that there does exist serious
Oitellectual opposition to the
Vietnam conflict in American
Society.
"Depraved War"

With which the liberal view in
American politics finds expression in the press. Any anti-war
demonstration is given good publicity. He expressed fear, however, that such publicity might
serve only to cement opinion
against the aims of the demonstrators.
Dr. Brick further said that he
does not believe 'that America
has ever engaged in war-making
in so depraved a manner as it is
presently engaged in Vietnam. He
said that there might be a tendency on the part of the governmental bureaucracy to try to

a war.

conscientious objectors were becoming more numerous, with one

this growing opposition by hints
of alternative service in the Peace
Corps or VISTA.
He believed, however, that the
vast majority of middle class
America was not willing to stand
up for its principles to the extent
of going to jail. He also pointed
to a lack of knowledge, especially
on the part of lower class persons eligible for the draft, of the
details or even the existence of
conscientious objection.

By GARTH MACKENZIE
If one were to conduct a short
investigation of the situation of
American fraternities, he would
probably find that nearly every
major university in the country
has its so-called fraternity row.
At the University of Maryland,
as is the wide-spread case, the
fraternities are clustered together on university owned land;
they are, correspondingly, considered campus organizations
and are therefore subject to all
campus restrictions on the use
of alcohol, social functions, and
gaiety in general.
To maintain efficient control over the sororities and fraternities, the university provides
each one with a house mother,
whose duty it is to keep the
members in line.
At Hopkins, however, the situation is distinctively different.
In accordance with the University's policy of non-interference,
the 14 social fraternities are
scattered more or less randomly
in the area immediately surrounding the campus. Their
houses stand on privately-owned
land and are owned or rented by
the national chapters.
Canterbury Road is the closest
thing Hopkins presently has in
the way of a fraternity row. Five
houses, including TEP, Beta, Phi
Gam, Phi Sig, and DU, are now
located either on Canterbury Rd.
or in the near vicinity.
The other houses stand along
Charles, St. Paul, and Calvert
Streets in the old area to the
south of the campus. The neighborhood condition in this section
is worsening—in the past few
weeks there has been an increasing number of incidents involv-

ing vandalism against both
houses and brothers.
If this decay continues, inevitably many of these fraternities will attempt to relocate
themselves north of Homewood
—most probably in Canterbury.
Move To Canterbury
When Phi Sigma Delta became the first Hopkins fraternity
to move onto Canterbury Rd.
several years ago, there 'was a
great amount of resistance from

the inhabitants of this exclusive neighborhood. The problem
culminated in the appearance
before the Maryland Supreme
Court of a law suit designed to
oust the fraternity from Canterbury. It was defeated.
Since then, as the other fraternities moved into the section,
the neighbors have constantly
complained about noisy parties,
parking problems, and general

By PETER BROWNBACK,
war correspondent

Rotten, lousy, miserable weather prevailed as it usually does
when the Army is getting ready
to send its men into combat. At

night it was cold enough to make
a man wish for his gloves, but
the orders to wear them has not
yet been given.
There had been none of the
usual joking in the barracks tonight. Instead, the time had been
spent polishing the boots and
cleaning the rifles.
Everyone wanted to be sure
that his rifle would not misfire
the next day, and they all tried

desperately to remember what
Sergeant Funk had told them
about the best way to insure
safe firing. ,
Not many of the men felt
like talking anyway. They were
thinking their own thoughts and
reconciling themselves with what
was to be. A lot of their thoughts
went back to the training which
was to be so important the next
day. Three courses were most
clearly remembered.
Major Stultzenmueller's course
in fire and maneuver was one of
these. Fire and maneuver, the
basic means of advancing on an
enemy who has a better tactical
position, would enable them to
be effective in case they encountered a larger force of the
aggressor.
Sergeant-Major Ray's course
in combat formations would enable their squad leader to control them without having to explain step by step what he wanted them to do.

Their mission was to provide
confirmation of intelligence given
by the POW's to the S-3, the intelligence officer. This was to be

The dispute over the refusal
of the Marylander barber shop
to give haircuts to Negroes, including those who are students
at Hopkins, continues with the
prospect of Student Council action a possibility.
The Student Council discussed
the matter at their weekly meeting and voted to allot two dollars to Alan Beal, a Hopkins
student and a Negro in order to
get a haircut at the Marylander.
Beal was refused service by the
manager on the grounds that he
(the manager) was not trained
to cut a Negro's hair. He subsequently stated that none of the
other barbers working in his
shop have the necessary training.
Sam Barranco, manager of the
Hopkins Barber Shop in Levering Hall concurred. He said that
"cutting a colored man's hair
does require extra training" and
that "most barbers in Baltimore
don't have the training." He
added, however, that "Here at
Hopkins we do the best for anyone regardless of color, race or
creed."
As an additional tactic, the
student delegation which confronted Mr. De Ruggiero, also

discussed the matter with the
manager of the Marylander
Apartments, the building in
which the barber shop is located.
When the students presented the
possibility of a picket outside
the apartments, he said that he
did not care.
The conflict was precipitated
a few weeks ago when Victor Da
Ruggiero, the manager of the
barber shop refused to cut the
hair of a Negro who was also a
Hopkins student. Last week, a
group of students decided to
take action and called a meeting
of Hopkins students to discuss
the situation. It was decided at
the meeting that a delegation of
students should speak to Mr. De
Ruggiero and try to obtain concessions from him. If that failed,
a picket and boycott were
planned.
The delegation met with the
barber who allegedly said that
he would give haircuts to Negroes one day each week. Not
satisfied, Stephen Shriver, who
chaired the student meeting on
the controversy, pressed for wider
concessions. According to Shrivel-, Mr. De Ruggiero finally
agreed to cut the hair of any
Hopkins student..

Dr. John White, Chairman of

here, was named this week to
head regional operations of Jacqueline Kennedy's Committee to
Rescue Italian Art.
The aim of the committee will
be to contribute financial support to the salvage and restoration of works of art damaged
when floods ravaged northeastern Italy last week.
Worst Disaster
The disaster has been called
Italy's worst in recent history.
Estimates of damage range into
the billions of dollars for works
of art alone.
Hard hit by the high rising
flood waters were the Uffizi Galleries, the National Library,
Giotto's Campanile, the Pazzi
Chapel, San Lorenzo and the
Medici Chapels.
In Venice, waters reached their
highest flood level in two centuries, and experts fear that the
city, its foundations weakened,

Lippi, Maasaccio, and Simone
Martini were completely destroyed.
Informed sources estimate that
20 years will be needed to restore what remains.

PAGE THREE

One of the season's most important art events will take
place at The Baltimore Museum
of Art beginning December 13
when the museum presents "Andrew Wyeth: A Comprehensive
Exhibition."
The Baltimore Museum of Art
is one of the three museums in
the country to hold the exhibition following its opening presentation at The Pennsylvania
Academy of Fine Arts which organized this ambitious assemblage of works. Wyatt is considered America's pre-eminent realist painter, and perhaps the
most popular of America's living artists.
Wyeth is almost always classified as a realist, though he may
not describe himself as such. His
paintings are representational,
that is, the objects are recognizable and familiar—people, boats
animals, windows, landscape—
but what he does with color,
composition and his own creative
expression may not go down in
art history as pure realism.
Agnes Mongan of the Fogg
Art Museum, an authoritative
critic of Wyeth, wrote in a recent
publication about him: "As is
true of every real artist, his preference and use saf color is deeply
personal, again often with symbolic overtones. He loves the
colors of dry grass and of fresh
grass, and the russet of autumn
leaves, 'the dusty beauty' of a
winter beehive, olive-greens and
mustardy yellows, the contrast
of silvery and golden tones, and
over and over, or more than a
note, of blue: the faded, worn
blue of an old denim coat, a
blue measure, a blue scale, a
blue mussel shell, a patch of blue
water, a bit of blue sky, or a box

or two of blueberries.
"In the best sense of the
word, Andrew Wyeth is a regional artist, for the scenes he
draws and paints are chosen
from two regions he knows and
loves so well. But in the last
analysis the drawings and paintings are no more regional than
the seasons themselves and the
effects these seasons have on the
lives of those who live in and
through them."
Many of the best paintings by
Wyeth will be shown in the
forthcoming exhibition, including "Maga's Daughter", 1966,
lent by the artist; "The Mill",
1958, lent by Mrs. Andrew Wyeth; "Four Poster", 1946, lent by
Mr. and Mrs. Roger Milliken of
South Carolina; "Young America", 1950, lent by the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts;
"Grape Wine", 1966, lent by M.
Knoedler and Company, New
York; and "The Slip", 1958, lent
by Mrs. Andrew Wyeth.
Altogether, some 200 paintings
and drawings will be shown,
drawn from museums and private collections around America.
An admission charge of $1.00
to the Wyeth exhibition areas
will be made; general admission

tire week and not just weekends.
Goucher President Kraushaar
sent the approved curfew to the

been unanimously approved by

one which was proposed for the

was defeated by the SAC. The
matter was reopened this Year
by changing the resolution so
that it applied only to the senior
and junior classes.
Kraushaar, in approving the
curfew, stated, "To reduce the
risks of trying out the curfew
proposal, I'm approving the selfdetermined curfew for a one
year period for the senior class
only."
Reliable Goucher sources said
that there was a possibility of
the curfew being extended to
juniors later in the year.

Book Review

Manchild in the Promised Land
By BARON WORMSER
Duji. Junkie. Evangelism. Muslims. Harlem is a ruin. The bowels of America. A dream. Mugger.
Hustler. Peddler. Uptown New
York City. Harlem is a ruin.
Harlem is nowhere.
Claude Brown, amid a welter
of sociological idiocy, governmental absurdity, and mawkish
hypocrisy, has written •a book
Manchild In The Promised Land
(Signet paper 95c) about his
growing up in Harlem in the
'40's and '59's which is easily the
most brilliant work by a Negro
author since Ralph Ellison's Invisible Man.
Aim of Novel
Manchild in the Promised Land
resembles the stated aim of Ellison's novel in that it is "a
combination of the marvelous
and the terrible" and follows
James Baldwin's dictum that the
novel should be written wholly
out of experience. It reflects not
what Life Magazine refers pictorially to as the "Negro experience" but as Ellison and Baldwin have done "the American experience". For Harlem is certainly an American symbol. Ralph
Ellison has written, "Harlem is
the scene and symbol of the
Negro's perpetual alienation in
the land of his birth." Harlem as
Norman Mailer has reflected is
a kind of hell within a hell.
Dabbling Man

Students, Faculty To Mix
Faculty members and students will have the opportunity
to mingle informally every week
at Levering. Starting December
I, an informal coffee hour will
be held in the Sherwood Room
every Thursday.

will be able to mingle and chat.
There will be no structured
format. People will be free to
come and go as they please.
Refreshments will be provided
during the hour. The coffee and
donuts will be free.

The program is being coordinated by Bill Benzon, SA cabinet member, and Dr. Neville
Oyson-Hudson, anthropologist.
the two have sent letters to all
taculty members and have obtained commitments from many
faculty members to drop in during the hour.
The professors and students

In citing the need for this
program, Benzon quoted from
the Undergraduate catalogue,
"But above all, a university is a
community of people bound together in a magnificent enterprise, the enterprise of learning."
According to Benzon, most of
the interaction between professors and students comes on a

"functionary" level, as students
and teachers. "There is not
enough contact as people," he
stated.
Benzon added that if the response to the coffee hours was
favorable, the program could be
expanded.

By M. PAUL
The Campus Parking and Traffic Committee will act this month
on proposals to erect a five-story
parking garage west of the Aeronautics Building.
If an informal campus poll
shows favorable interest in the
structure, the Committee will ask
for University approval early in
1967.
No plans have been drawn yet
for the garage, but the area has
been surveyed by a consulting
firm hired by the Parking Committee.
Park It Yourself
The firm recommends a multilevel, self-park, pay garage, containing space for 927 cars. Estimated cost is $2,500,000.
Construction would be financed
by government loans, to be paid
off through parking fees. Garage
privileges would cost approximately $23.00 per space annually.
The University currently has
parking space for 962 cars. Its
largest lot, number four, contains
240 spaces.
Permits Issued
At the same time a total 9,500
parking permits have been issued

for the 1966-67 school year.
"There is a need for more space
for both the day and evening
school," said William Campbell,
Assistant Plant Manager.
"The problem is worse at night
school, but it's also severe between ten in the morning and
three in the afternoon."
No short term solutions have
been proposed, but Campbell
noted that the employment of
additional parking guards this
year has helped control the situation to a certain degree.
Park on Streets
He also remarked, however,
that problems have been compounded ever since the city
tightened parking regulations on
streets surrounding the campus.
"The city put in two-hour
meters on the south side of Art
Museum Drive and a two-hour
parking limit on the north side,"
he pointed out."Formerly, streets
like this would handle our overflow."
A garage is favored over the
surfacing of more lots since a
building would take up less
space, according to the Parking
Committee.

Brick-a-Brack
By HENRY M. HOCHERMAN
Upon entering the Eisenhower
Library these days, one can not
help but have his eyesight assailed by a collection of cardboard
and paint purported to be an
architect's rendering of the New
South Quad. Sick and tired —Of
being behind in the University
Space Race, the stately old Hop
Will add 700,000 square feet
(enough room to put down 4,345,786 No Doz tablets end to
end) of office and classroom
sPace in the next 25 years. Wonderful.
The new buildings, designed by
Horatio W. Shubocks, president
Of the famous architectural firm
Ott Shubocks, Redbrick, Trimsworth and Gauche, will abandon
the old Georgian style for which
the Hopkins has long been noted,
and will adopt a new, modern
look, a cross, it would appear,
between Long Island High School
Provincial and International
House of Pancakes contemporary, an architectural form very
Popular among the more forward looking state schools. Architect Shubocks, who made his
name in the packaging industry
designing the now famous Cap'n
Crunch and Nabisco Shredded
Wheat boxes, has applied his
Packaging talents to architecture. "We get more space," he
has been quoted as saying, "by
sticking to tried and true principles. None of this old time
Georgian stuff for me." In keeping with Mr. Shubocks' architectural ideals, the New South
Quad will appear, from the air,
much like a collection of Kleenex
boxes worshipping a central milk
container. Purists need not fear
however, for Plant Manager
Wesley Taylor, who is working
hand in glove with Shubocks, has
assured the Hopkins community
that the new buildings will be of
red brick construction and will
be crowned with white trim. An
audible sigh of relief was heard
at this declaration.
Problems of Georgian fenestration have been eliminated by
eliminating windows, in keeping
With the great aesthetic precedent set by the New Classroom
Building, and the buildings will
of course be fully air conditioned
for those who enjoy artificial air

model on Main Level of Eisenhower does not show the interiors of the proposed buildings,

that they will be of the same
structurally strong and artistically balanced bathroom tile
that now adorns stodgy, old fashioned, un-airconditioned, Gilman
Hall. These tiles will provide an
air of the sterile which Mr.
Taylor feels, it would appear,
adds so much to an academic
environment.
One can not help but agree
that abandoning the old Georgian style is a step forward.
Why build warm, friendly, notoriously inefficient Georgian Buildings one can study and think inis supedintendent of the dining
stead in wonderful, shiny, cool,
red and white monuments to the
foresight of man, which bespeak
about as much personality as a
delivery from the Greenspring
dairy, and are about as inviting
as a life raft with the air let out.
In announcing the proposed
new construction, the University
has thrust itself into the vanguard of university expansion,
and the new buildings, coupled to
the newly renovated Gilman
Hall, will present a new and exciting face for The Hopkins,
equal to the greatest universities
and motels in the nation.
The model of the New South
Quad in the Library stands as a

The Bell System has many small, automatic
telephone offices around the
country.The equipment in them
could operate unattended for
ten years or so, but for a problem.
The many electric motors in those offices
needed lubrication at least once a year. Heat
from the motors dried up the bearing oils,
thus entailing costly annual maintenance:
To stamp out this problem, many tests
were conducted at Bell Telephone
Laboratories. Lubricant engineer George H. Kitchen decided
to do a basic experiment that
would provide a motor with the
worst possible conditions. He deliberately set

out to ruin some ball bearings
by smearing them with an
icky guck called molybdenum
disulfide (MoS2).

STUDY IN
SOUTHERN FRANCE

Swock! This solid lubricant, used a certain
way, actually increased the life expectancy
of the ball bearings by a factor
often! Now the motors can run
for at least a decade without
lubrication.
We've learned from our
!`failures." Our aim: investigate
everything.

really be said to "fail" is the
one that is never tried,

from A Mr Pi R2 to E Ma Now she says he's found the formula
for success with her. All he has to do is mutter "Coronet R/T," and
I get thrown for a loss. Believe me, this is no equilateral triangle
that I'm in. Qutside of telling me to bench myself, have you any
advice?

second half heroics a week ago,
the varsity football team will try
to avert a winless season tomorrow by upsetting Western Maryland just as it did last year.
Boosting Jay hopes for a repeat of '65's 24-6 upset over the
Terrors were the efforts of Feely,
who completed seven of ten
passes for 130 yards and two
touchdowns in his varsity quarterbacking debut, and the strong
beam comeback that brought the
Jays from a two touchdown halftime deficit to a 14-14 tie with
heavily favored Dickinson.
Western Maryland, for its
part, should make this a difficult
bask despite its 3-5 record. The
Green Terrors have played what
is on the whole a tougher schedule than that of Hopkins and, in
somplementing
their
usually
etrong running game with a capable aerial attack, have put together one of the deepest and
Most explosive offensive backfields in the area.
Sprint Champ
Heading this crew is 5-9, 160
pound Mason - Dixon sprint
champ Dana Huseman, regarded
by scout Bob Scott as "the best
breakaway threat in the Middle
.Atlantic." He has averaged 6.5
yards per carry in the games
Scouted and is a dangerous deep
'deceiver.
The other starters are 5-9, 185
pound .soph halfback Jerry Borg, a versatile performer who
runs with some power, can move
hi the open field, and is a capable punter and place kicker;
6-0 175 pound freshman quarterback Bruce Bozman, cause of
the increased Terror air emphasis this year; and fullback Earl
Dietrich, a good power runner.

By JEFF LAUREN
After splitting its last two
games, the varsity soccer team
will try to end the season on a
winning note tomorrow at Dickinson.
Saturday the Bluejays were
trying for their third straight
win but were stopped cold by
Drexel, 2-0. Hopkins was hampered by the absence of Pablo
Drobny, the team's high scorer,
and defensive starters Roger
Purdom and Stu Hogdson. Hodgson suffered a torn thigh muscle
and is out for the season.
Coach Gary Barrette shuffled his players in an attempt
to make up for the losses as
he shifted Dave Rockwell to
halfback and put Ken Torrington
in Rockwell's fullback spot. But
he could not help the Bluejays
score. They all played well, but
missed their chances to score
when they took eight shots in
the first period without any hitting.
Then with only a minute and
a half left, in the first period,
Drexel scored two goals and the
game was over. Hopkins was outshot 17-15, but hustled most of
the game until they tired in the
last period.
The Drexel goalie made some
spectacular saves to keep the
Bluejays from scoring. Soph Carl
Ahrendt started in place of
Drobny, and showed poise and
good play.
Tuesday the Jays traveled to

Western Maryland looking for a
victory. This time co-captain
Drobny was able to play and he
sparked Hopkins to a 5-2 win,
bringing their season record to
three victories and six losses. The
defense was tight and played another fine game as they have
shown continual improvement
from mid-season on.
On offense, Drobny kicked two
goaLs, making that thirteen for
the season. Wes Bachur had his
best day of the year, also scoring two goals. Scoring number
five, sophomore Art Guerin got
his first goal of the season.
Guerin, the high sewer on last
year's freshmen team, has been
a starter all season, and has
played well throughout. He
scored Tuesday on a header from
a corner kick.
A Better Half
Barrette has high hopes for
tomorrow's game against Dickinson. He feels that if the Bluejays can win tomorrow, then
their season would be more successful than their record shows.
They would have won four out
of their last five games after
their 0-5 start.
Dickinson is 2-7 on the year,
but is much better than its record. They lost several close
games to good teams. For comparison, Dickinson beat Washington College 5-1, while Hopkins won by a score of 4-1. Both
teams should be evenly matched.
with a good battle in the making.,
